title: 115_hr666
content: The Act titled "Department of Homeland Security Insider Threat and Mitigation Act of 2017" establishes an Insider Threat Program under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Secretary will establish an Insider Threat Program within the Department to provide training, investigative support, and conduct risk mitigation activities for insider threats. Additionally, a Steering Committee will be formed with key personnel to oversee the program. The Steering Committee, led by the Vice Chair, includes representatives from various offices within the Department to address insider threats to critical assets. Responsibilities include regular meetings to discuss cases and issues related to insider threats. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis, Chief Security Officer, and Steering Committee will develop a holistic strategy to address insider threats, implement measures department-wide, document policies, and conduct risk assessments. The Department will develop a strategy to address insider threats, implement measures, document policies, and conduct risk assessments. This includes examining best practices, developing a timeline for deploying workplace monitoring technologies, and consulting with stakeholders to ensure the Insider Threat Program is effective. The Insider Threat Program will be informed by current information on threats, best practices, and technology. Metrics on the effectiveness of the Department's insider threat mitigation efforts will be developed, collected, and reported. Definitions include critical assets as essential elements for the Department's mission and insiders as those with access to classified national security information within the Department. The term 'insider threat' refers to the risk of an individual with authorized access causing harm to the security of the United States, including damage to the country. This includes individuals within the Armed Forces, consultants, contractors, and personnel with security clearances granted by the Department. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit a report on how the Department of Homeland Security and its components are addressing insider threats, including espionage, terrorism, unauthorized disclosure of classified information, and resource degradation. Homeland Security has implemented a strategy to address insider threats, including risk assessments of critical assets and insider threat training for employees. The effectiveness of the Insider Threat Program is evaluated based on collected metrics. Definitions for "critical assets", "insider", and "insider threat" are provided in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The table of contents of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended by a clerical amendment. The Homeland Security Act of 2002's table of contents is amended by adding a new item, "Sec. 104. Insider Threat Program." This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on January 31, 2017.
